manuscript.title: el-Muhtasar (المختصر)
manuscript.author: Kudûrî, Ebü'l-Hüseyn Ahmed b. Muhammed b. Ahmed el-Bağdâdî el-Kudûrî (أبو الحسين أحمد بن محمد القدوري) (d. 428/1037)
manuscript.notes: Dated AH 1109 / CE 1697–1698. Arabic text in naskh script. Section headings written in red ink (bölüm başlıkları kırmızı mürekkeple yazılmıştır). The binding is a patterned paper-covered board (desenli kâğıt kaplı mukavva) with dark red/burgundy leather spine, outer edges, and flap (sertab bordo meşin mıkleplı).

paper_decoration.summary: The YEK kagit_ozellikleri field describes the paper as 'Abadi ve suyolu filigranli mulevven' — abadi paper with chain-line watermarks (suyolu filigranı), colored (mülevven). Visual examination of p003 shows a distinctly warm orangish-brownish tone that is consistent with a mülevven (colored/dyed) paper ground but cannot be definitively distinguished from paper aging or oxidation at available resolution. The catalogue's explicit use of the term 'mülevven' supports the identification of intentional coloring, making this a probable rather than confirmed record. No gold decoration or elaborate margin ornament is noted; the decoration programme is modest and consistent with a provincial fiqh manuscript of the late 17th century.

technique_terms.ottoman: mülevven kâğıt; âbâdî kâğıt; suyolu filigranı

key_indicators: Dated AH 1109 / CE 1697–1698 — late 17th-century Ottoman production, consistent with widespread use of mülevven and âbâdî paper in Ottoman fiqh manuscripts of this period
Diyarbakır İl Halk Kütüphanesi provenance suggests provincial Anatolian production rather than Istanbul court context
Naskh script and modest decoration programme (red section headings only) are characteristic of functional scholarly manuscripts, not luxury court commissions
cross_tradition_caveats: Mülevven (colored) paper was produced and used across Ottoman, Safavid, and Mughal contexts; the paper color alone cannot establish tradition or centre
The warm tone seen in p003 may result from aging or oxidation rather than intentional dyeing — this is the primary limiting factor for the probable verdict
No scribal colophon specifying place of production is recorded in the available catalogue data

paper.description: Âbâdî paper with chain-line watermarks (suyolu filigranı), colored (mülevven). Âbâdî is a well-known quality paper type used extensively in Ottoman manuscript production; chain-line watermarks indicate a laid paper structure. The warm orangish-brown tone visible in p003 may reflect either intentional dyeing or subsequent aging.
paper.watermark: Suyolu filigranı (chain-line watermarks; paper type consistent with Eastern or European laid paper)
paper.color: Mülevven — warm orange-brown tone observed on p003; intentional coloring probable but not visually confirmed with certainty

ruling.description: Bölüm başlıkları kırmızı mürekkeple yazılmıştır (section headings in red ink). No elaborate cedvel or framing system is noted in the catalogue.

binding.description: Sırtı kenarlıkları ve sertabı bordo meşin mıkleplı, desenli kâğıt kaplı mukavva cilt. Board binding (mukavva) covered in patterned paper (desenli kâğıt), with dark red/burgundy leather (bordo meşin) on spine, outer edges, and envelope flap (mıklep). The patterned paper on the binding covers is distinct from the text-block paper and is not counted as manuscript paper decoration.
binding.binding_type: Board binding with patterned paper covers and leather spine/edges/flap

terms_used.english: Colored / dyed paper: paper that has been dyed or tinted in a single color before writing. In Ottoman manuscripts, mülevven papers appear in warm tones (yellow, orange, rose, blue, green) produced using organic dyes. Distinguished from gold-worked (zerkâri) and gold-sprinkled (zerefşân) papers.

Abadi paper: a well-known quality paper type associated with fine-quality Eastern (Iranian/Ottoman) laid paper. Used for luxury and semi-luxury manuscripts in the Ottoman period. Frequently appears as a base paper for mülevven (colored), zerefşân (gold-sprinkled), or zerkâri (gold-worked) treatment.

Chain-line watermark (suyolu filigranı): translucent parallel lines formed in laid paper by the chain wires of the papermaking mould. Distinct from figurative watermarks (filigranı); here described in the YEK catalogue as a paper type descriptor for âbâdî paper.

Mukhtasar: an abridgement or compendium; as a genre, refers to condensed manuals of Islamic jurisprudence. Al-Kudūrī's Mukhtasar is one of the most widely copied Ḥanafī fiqh primers, produced in large numbers across Ottoman, Safavid, and Mughal manuscript workshops.

bibliography.relevance: Surveys the history of paper types, including âbâdî and laid papers, across the Islamic manuscript tradition; relevant to contextualizing the paper stock of this late 17th-century Diyarbakır manuscript.

bibliography.relevance: Specialized study of Islamic paper types and papermaking, with attention to the identification of paper varieties including âbâdî paper and laid papers with chain-line structures; relevant to the codicological description of the paper stock of this manuscript.

suggested_collections.reason: Home collection; adjacent shelfmarks may share paper stock and binding conventions, enabling comparative assessment of local manuscript production patterns.

Holds numerous late Ottoman fiqh manuscripts (al-Kudūrī copies are common) on comparable mülevven and âbâdî paper stocks; comparative examination would assist in assessing whether the warm-toned paper is intentionally colored or aged.

provenance.notes: Held in the Diyarbakır İl Halk Kütüphanesi (Diyarbakır Provincial Public Library), southeastern Turkey. No donor, waqf, or previous shelfmark information is recorded in the available catalogue data. The dated AH 1109 / CE 1697–1698 colophon is the primary fixed point for dating. The provincial collection context and modest binding (patterned paper boards with leather) suggest non-capital-city production, consistent with the widespread copying of al-Kudūrī's Mukhtasar as a standard madrasa text across the Ottoman Empire.
